Name: Tras el Unicornio: Searching the Unicorn
Description:
According to a legend in 1471 by order of Henry IV King of Castille, called the Impotent, set out one expedition to Africa, beyond the land of the Moors.
The secret aim of this expedition was to hunt a unicorn, since it was assumed that the horn of this mythological creature could increase the virility of the king.
In 1946 the results of the exhumation of the corpse of Henry IV  alongside the king's mummified remains found a gray spindle object, which was proved to be a fragment of African rhino horn.

So begins and ends the novel "In Search of the Unicorn" by Juan Eslava Galan awarderd Planeta Prize in 1987, being the original idea for this game. Each player leads an expedition sent to hunt the unicorn, but in the way they could get other valuable things like gold, trading on the Silk Road and to evangelize people in the name of his master Henry IV of Castille. All this if the expeditioners survived the attacks of nomade tribes with whom they have to fight. Many dangers and soldiers will die during the way and what is worse, maybe you the leader will also fall before reaching your goal ... who will get the horn and gets the grace of the king?

---

En 1471 por orden de Enrique IV de Castilla, llamado el Impotente, parte una expedición desde Segovia con destino los pastizales de Africa, más allá de la tierra de los moros.
El objetivo secreto de esta expedición era cazar un unicornio, ya que se suponía que su cuerno podía aumentar la virilidad del rey.
Según reza el Acta de la Exhumación del cadáver de Enrique IV de 1946, junto a los restos momificados del rey se encontró un objeto fusiforme gris, que una vez identificado por el C.S.I.C. resultó ser un fragmento de cuerno de rinoceronte africano.

Así comienza y termina la novela “En busca del unicornio” de Juan Eslava Galán  que fue Premio Planeta en 1987, y  que sirve como idea para este juego. Cada jugador dirige una expedición para cazar el unicornio, pero por el camino podrá conseguir oro, comerciar en la ruta de la seda y hasta evangelizar pueblos para ensalzar la figura de su señor Enrique IV de Castilla. Todo esto si sobrevive a los ataques de los pueblos nómadas con los que tendrá que luchar. A lo largo de la expedición es posible que tus compañeros pierdan la vida y lo que es peor, a lo mejor tu también caes…¿serás tu quien gane el favor del rey?

Name: Mad Bishops
Description:
Mad Bishops is a two-player game which uses a 10x10 checkerboard, 25 red checkers and 25 blue checkers.  The board is initially set up as shown in the figure.

The checkers function like Chess bishops with two restrictions.  On your turn you must either kill, or move into position to kill.  If a checker is already in position to kill, it can only be used to kill. Killing is not mandatory.  I.e. if you can move an unengaged checker to engage the enemy, you can do that instead.

Mad Bishops is a game of annihilation.  I.e., you must kill all enemy checkers to win.

Name: Bid$
Description:
From the box:

"Bid$ is a truly challenging experience that is totally unique from most board games in that any property is available, if you are willing to bid the right price.  You can taste the satisfaction of forcing your opponents to pay too much for their modest properties, or jump at the opportunity of stealing a legitimate good deal by being shrewd and cunning.  If you like fast paced competitive fun that keeps the chance factor to a minimum, try Bid$, the game where you do control your own destiny."

Object of the game (2-6 players) - To make as much money as possible by buying stores and eventually towers.  Each player picks a marker and starts at "receive $1500" (you do not collect the money until you have gone around the board once).  All players play around the outside edge (lower level) and can only move into the upper level (inside edge) with a bank payment of $15,000.  The players begin by rolling the dice, and the player with with the highest number starts first.  The rest of the order is determined by going clockwise.  When play begins, if a player rolls doubles, he/she is allowed to go again.  The player keeps rolling until he/she stops getting doubles (property that you hit along the way must be bid on or if it is owned the owner must be paid).  Each player is given $21,000 at the start of the game.  When a property is landed on, the bidding starts.

Name: Colonnade
Description:
Colonnade is a two person game which uses a 1x8 board, 12 red checkers and 12 blue checkers.  The board is initially set up as shown in the figure.

You can pick up any one of your checkers from a stack, carrying the checkers above it along, and place it onto an adjacent stack that’s topped with a checker of your color. (A stack can be of height 1.)  Complete such a move with a discard.  I.e. if two like-colored checkers are adjacent in a stack, discard one of the two checkers.

You can also move a checker down to an unoccupied square.  You can't slide a bottom checker sideways to an unoccupied square.

The last player to have a move available wins.  I.e. if you don't have a move available on your turn, you lose.

Name: Wanderlust
Description:
In Wanderlust, you are racing through an arrow maze, trying to pick up the right Things and take those Things where you can win with them.

The playing area consists of a 6x7 grid of double-sided tiles. On one face, the tiles display the possible moves and on the other, places for winning and actions available to the players. After having done the action or move shown on a tile, the player flips the tile over.

Like Fluxx, the Goals are indefinite, but unlike Fluxx, Wanderlust requires much more turn-by-turn planning.

Complete rules, example turns, and PDFs are available at:
http://ceruleansgames.tripod.com/wanderlust.htm

Name: Sälles äventyr
Description: A children's game that is not actually about the wacky adventures of the eponymous seal mascot, but a way of teaching seamanship and environmental care among other things. Players navigate the archipelago on the game board with their boats and try to land on special tiles where they can gain point tokens. Depending on the colour of the tile, this is done by answering questions, drawing pictures or giving small performances. As an added twist, only some of the point tokens actually represent real points, meaning the scores of the players are hidden until the end of the game.

Name: Steel Will: 479 BC, The Battle of Plataea
Description:
With a strong will like steel Spartans responsed to the call of war:
...
"Go tell the Spartans, stranger passing by,
that here, obedient to their law, we lie."
-Simonides.
...
"During the 2nd Persian Invasion to Greece  and after the battles of Thermopylae, Artemision and Boeotia led by Xerxes himself, the Persians retreated after their first loss at the naval Battle of Salamis. Persian forces retreated to Asia and General Mardonius returned to finish what the Persian King has started. He built a fortified camp outside Plataea.

Greeks have assembled an army allied by many cities of ancient Greece. Spartans led the forces of Peloponnesos , Athenians answered the call with many other cities. It was Summer of 479 BC where the two armies has met each other opposed , even if at the Percian forces had many greek traitors  and mercenaries,  for a battle that actually ended the Persian vanquishment.

General Mardonius met his own destiny in this battle, and General Pausanias from Sparta, has archived a victory , even if their forces were outnumbered."

"Steel Will: 479 BC, The Battle of Plataea" is a history-themed wargame for two players that simulates that battle. With an abstract taste of gameplay, the core of classic historic-wargame and the feeling of a new approach at combat mechanism, we tried to create something that keeps the interest of the players alive!"

Name: Warhammer: Forces of Fantasy
Description:
A box set of three books containing additional rules and scenarios for first edition Warhammer:

Volume 1: Forces of Fantasy
Volume 2: Fighting Fantasy Battles
Volume 3: Arcane Magics

These include extended rules for fleshing out Warhammer armies, more battle rules (particularly for various levels of unit organization), and rules for the use of magic in the game.

Name: Solve and Settle
Description:
From game designer:

This educational game, meant to help reinforce solving simple Algebraic equations, puts you in the roll of an explorer of a newly discovered land competing against other explorers in an effort to settle the most territories of the land.

The land consists of four different types of territories to settle.  The territories are the Plains, the Wetlands, the Forest, and the Mountains.

Each card represents a different territory and contains an equation to be solved.  In order to settle a territory one must possess a card containing the solution to the algebraic equation given on any unoccupied territory.  Forming empires can lead to overthrowing your opponent’s settlements.  But beware, if your opponent can fend off your attack, their settlements become even stronger than before.

The person who settles the most territories rules the land!

Name: Ravening Hordes: The Official Warhammer Battle Army Lists
Description: A supplement for 2nd edition Warhammer that featured full army lists for that edition of the game - the immediate ancestor of the 3rd edition supplement, Warhammer Armies.  Included are rules for various armies along with points values, wargear, and full stats for the variety of units included with each.

Name: Warhammer: Dark Shadows
Description: A campaign book for the 2001 WFB campaign of the same name - includes rules for fighting in the campaign setting of Albion, including descriptions of the setting, special army lists for running battles, the running of the campaing itself, etc.

Name: Warhammer: Chronicles 2003
Description: The Warhammer Fantasy Battle equivalent of Warhammer 40,000's Chapter Approved - a short-lived annual (the "Chronicles" name gets on the cover starting with the second annual - the first simply says "Annual"), collecting new and experimental rules from White Dwarf for Warhammer 6th edition.  These include rules for combat as well as new or revised army lists or special rules for various armies that didn't make it into the army books of the 6th edition.  Like Chapter Approved, each new edition was published in the year prior to the year mentioned in its title.

Name: Junk Mail
Description:
Are you tired of all the SPAM emails you get on a daily basis in your inbox? Well here is your chance to spam someone else for a change.

Junk Mail is card game all about spamming other people and trying to protect yourself. You will play spam cards on your opponents and give yourself firewalls, employees and professions for protection and better chances to spam someone else. Maybe you can use a hacker or an advertising rep. to help your cause.
Families: Theme: Mail / Stamps / The Post Office

Name: Honk!
Description:
Do you drive in traffic on a daily basis? How stressful is it dealing with all those crazy drivers every morning and night? Welcome to HONK! the board game all about driving through traffic.
The object of the game is to navigate your car down the freeway and be the first to make it home. That would be simple, but everyone else is trying to do the same thing. Each player has a handful of cards and a number of actions. A player may use cards to gain special movements, inhibit the movement of other players, or move cars out of way. The other thing players can do is strategically move their car. Either way, making it down the freeway is a hoot with flat tires, stalled cars, accidents, and of course the police. Keep your eyes open as this one will be for sale soon!

Name: Warhammer (Sixth Edition): The General's Compendium
Description: An optional rules supplement for Warhammer 6th edition with a focus on campaigns.  Included are rules for running several different kinds of campaigns (including map-based and decision trees), plus rules for special locations and environments and a number of scenarios to run during campaigns.

Name: Satzglieder
Description: Learning game which can teach children to recognize sentence constituents. These are printed on little cards and can be combined in different ways. The goal is to form sentences to match the picture tiles included in the game.

Name: Epic Dice Battles: Japanese Warfare
Description:
EDB: Japanese Warfare was submitted for the "Dicefest Contest - A Tribute to Chessex" held in 2010.

It uses 36 dice in each players color to represent armies, units, actions, and rice production by each player.
Tokens are added to the game to enable hidden unit assignments to the armies, as well as an amount of castles and resources.

Set in feudal Japan, in the end of the Muromachi Period (1136 till 1568 A.D.) before firearms ever made it to the islands, the battles will be conducted between unit of archers, cavalry and Samurai.

EDB: Japanese Warfare is supposed to be the first of a series of games, which use a vast number of dice to represent units in battle scenarios and a simple action-point system to build and strengthen ones armies.

Name: Chess³
Description:
"An environmental sculpture in chrome steel and crystal clear polished playing boards which moves chess into an intriguing new dimension." (side of box Description)

This game is a relatively straightforward 3-Dimensional extrapolation of the standard chess concept, and as such the goal and theme are much the same, with one player each starting one the top and bottom boards.

Some of the moves for various pieces have been changed, with all pieces moving as per usual on one plane, but the movements from plane to plane of the Queen, Bishop, and Pawn are not as one would initially expect. Most other 3D moves are restricted to moving one square only directly above or below the initial position of the piece.

Board and set could also be used for several other Components: Three Dimensional Chess, as there are no original pieces.

Name: Bobby and Betty's Trip to the New York World's Fair
Description: A souvenir of the 1939 world fair. The board reveals a miniature representation of the futuristic fair. So players could enjoy the various New York attractions in the comfort of their homes.

Name: Snap Action Baseball
Description:
The thrill and action of real baseball! This tabletop baseball game has a "Snap-action" pitching mound that holds six balls and lets players control the speed of the pitch.
The "Snap-action" bat lets players control the power of the swing. Players hit the ball into the base hit pockets or go for a home run. The game includes scoring dials to record the score as the game progresses.

Changes your tabletop into a baseball stadium.

Name: Antagonist
Description:
War has come to the ninth century as rival lords (the players) fight to conquer the land. Each player rules a fortress and the surrounding realm. Warriors are dispatched fortress and towers, crossing mountains, rivers, and open fields to engage the enemy. Using economics, diplomacy, and warfare, each player attempts to expand his realm and conquer all enemy fortresses.


     Players create a unique geography before each game begins, so it's never the same game twice.
     Antagonist is a BIG table game with marauding warriors, changing seasons, burning villages, and limitless strategies.
     Straight-forward, intuitive rules with have you playing in minutes.


(From the games label)

Name: Battle Royale
Description:
War has come to the ninth century as rival lords (the players) fight to conquer the land. Each player rules a fortress and the surrounding realm. Warriors are dispatched fortress and towers, crossing mountains, rivers, and open fields to engage the enemy. Using economics, diplomacy, and warfare, each player attempts to expand his realm and conquer all enemy fortresses.


     Players create a unique geography before each game begins, so it's never the same game twice.
     Battle Royale is a 2-player version of Antagonist with marauding warriors, changing seasons, burning villages, and limitless strategies.
     Straight-forward, intuitive rules with have you playing in minutes.


(From the games label)

Name: The Personality Game
Description: In The Personality Game one player askes a multiple choice question to a random player. The player asking the question gets a point for correctly predicting what that player will say about themselves. The answering player's playing piece will point in a certain direction based on his answer. That direction leads to one of four different quadrants on a board representing a personality type.  At the end of the game, the place where a player's peice ends up indicates their personality.  There are also places on the board where players get stuck unless they can get other players to guess a word on a card from that personality type.  The stuck player lists examples of the word, without saying the word itself. If they match, they can move on.  Other players gain points for matching that word. The first player to score 6 points wins.

Name: Apaspil
Description: From the back of the box: How do you play Going Ape?  By roiling the dice and collecting fruits. Different for beginners and seasoned players, beginning players collect the same fruits but seasoned  players collect every fruit. The one who collects the most fruit wins and gets a monkey in reward. The one who has the most monkeys at the end gets the main prize.

Name: LEGO World Explorer DVD Game
Description:
Who will be first to Legoland? Go on an adventure through four different Lego Worlds as you make your way to Legoland! On every turn players use the remote control to complete on of six different types of activities on the DVD. You'll compete to win a Car Race Navigate a Maze, Shoot a Catapult, Spot the Difference, Play Hot Potato, or figure out the More or Less Lego's Challenge. Every time an activity is mastered the DVD instructs players how to move on the board. But watch out, it may tell players to move backward or switch places. The first player to reach Legoland wins! Game contains interactive DVD, game board, 6 Lego brick playing pieces, and instructions. For 2-6 players ages 6 and up.

--Back of Box

Name: Space Frontier
Description:
From the publisher:

"Space Frontier is a card game of space exploration. Can you colonize more planets with sufficient resources than the Invader fleet?

Choose from several different space ships to create your exploration fleet. Each ship has a different ability that is activated by discovering a planet with a specific resource type.

Once two systems have been fully explored (or the Invaders have explored one system), the game ends, and you add up the scores. If your point value is higher than the Invader's points, you win.

A variety of Invader ships let you adjust the difficulty of play, and advanced rules allow you to challenge yourself even further.

Space Frontier can be played solitaire, or with two players (head-to-head or cooperatively)."

Name: Soldat
Description:
Soldat is a set of rules for simulating squad level infantry combat during the early and mid Twentieth Century. The rules concentrate on the World Wars, but can also be used for Korea, Indochina and the early Arab-Israeli wars. 
Unlike the great majority of wargame rules for this period, Soldat concentrates on the role of the infantryman. Combat in both World Wars rapidly became a series of vicious, small unit actions, a classic confrontation at close quarters with no holds barred. As in most wars, the dirty business of winning battles fell to the infantryman. Despite the vast array of sophisticated and deadly weapons available to all sides, success or failure ultimately depended upon the ability of the foot soldier to take or hold ground.

Name: Kewbz
Description:
From the publisher's website:

In the clever, creative, competitive, and captivating game of Kewbz™, opposing players compete for ownership of 'tower units' by positioning the final cube on top. Each time a corner is made, a cube is stacked at the intersection. When multiple corners are created, then multiple cubes are added into play. Clever strategy moves give you the winning edge.

Name: Klirr
Description:
A card game with gaming money. Bluff the value of the cards to gain a million.

The Players randomly draw cards containing different values. they then declare the value of the card, either the real value or bluffing. If the claim is not challenged by any other player, the active player received the amount of money he declared from the bank. 
If it is challenged (called) and the player was bluffing, he needs to pay the double amount declared to the calling player. If he was not bluffing the calling player needs to pay the double amount to the active player.
The player with most money when all the cards have been played wins.

Name: ROLLette
Description:
From the box: Ready, set, ROLL! Land three or more marbles in a row and score!

Object: Be the first player to score 50 points. Score points by landing your marbles to create rows of three or more in the same quadrant.

User comment: The game consist of 25 marbles (5 each of 5 colors) and a circular board, about 12 inches in diameter. Around the outer rim of the board are 28  three-quarter inch holes. Between the holes and the rim of the board is where a player will roll his marble--in the style of a roulette wheel--and hope it lands in a desirable hole in a desirable quadrant of the board. Landing several marbles in a row gains points, whether they be three in a row of your color or of mixed colors.

Instructions are printed on the bottom of the box.

Name: The Trivia Game Of Ocala, Florida
Description:
This is a generic trivia style game with an Ocala, Florida business theme. Ocala is the home of an internationally famous horse breeding and training center. The game features a colorful board with locations representing various business locations and tourist attractions.

Players move around the board and answer questions. The first player to get all the way through the grid to the jackpot square is the winner. The game also supports team play.

(c)1985 G & J Ideas

Name: Munchkin Thumb Drive
Description:
User SummaryThere are two Munchkin thumb drives:

     Munchkin Opposable Thumb Drive (fantasy theme)
     Munchkin Zombies Removable Thumb Drive (zombie theme)


				
				
					Munchkin Opposable Thumb DriveSince this thumb drive is "opposable," you can pull it out once per game during your Looking For Trouble phase and fight it like a monster. Its level is equal to the last two digits of the current year. If you defeat the Opposable Thumb Drive, you get 1 level and 1 Treasure. Its Bad Stuff is "Reformatted! You are dead."

				
				
					Munchkin Zombies Removable Thumb DriveOnce per game, you may remove a monster from combat and place the Monster card in your hand. It grants neither levels nor treasure. If this was the only monster in the fight, the combat ends immediately. The current player may Loot The Room, but may not Look For Trouble.

Rules from the World of Munchkin website. Both are 2GB in size and are fully functional flash drives.

Part of the Munchkin series.

Name: Inspector McClue: Death by Chocolate
Description:
From the back of the box:

Everyone's a suspect when murder is on the menu. And with a Classic Detective Murder Mystery you have everything you need to serve up the perfect murder dinner party. First the invites, you choose which of your friends play which devious suspect and invite them to come along as that character. Then the shopping list, menu suggestions and recipes. Plus of course...a really tasty murder to solve. It will be drop dead fun, and by the end of the evening, one (or more) of the suspects, your 'friends', will be caught out as the murderer!

Name: Yvio: Thinx
Description:
From the German publisher website:
Die Thinx sind wahre Multitalente: Sie sprechen mehrere Sprachen, klingen mal wie das Rauschen eines Baches oder wie Verkehrslärm. Sie kennen verschiedene Tierarten und fordern unser Wissen heraus: Welche Thinx bilden die Paare? In welcher Reihenfolge müssen sie platziert werden? Und welche gehören zu einer Gruppe, welche nicht…?
Findet die richtigen Positionen der 8 intelligenten Thinx und enträtselt ihre geheimnisvollen Bande!
- spielbar als Solo- oder Gesellschaftsspiel
- Förderung der haptischen Wahrnehmung
- ideal auch im Therapie-Bereich einsetzbar

Translated by Google Translate:
The Thinx are true multi-talents: They speak several languages, sometimes sounding like the sound of a stream or as traffic noise. You know different animal species and a challenge to our knowledge: What are the Thinx couples? In what order they should be placed? And belonging to a group which does not ...?
Find the right positions of the 8 Thinx intelligent and deciphered their mysterious band!
- playable as a solo or party game
- Promotion of haptic perception
- ideal in the treatment area used

Additional description:
"Thinx" is a thinking and logic game. The four basic pieces (from the main box) and the additional four pieces of the "Thinx" pack will be dressed in futuristic deco buildings. The goal of the game is to solve the puzzles by proper arrangement of the pieces on the eight fields of the board. The difficulty level rises from round to round. 
 In "Thinx" there are 3 different types of challenges:
- "Pair-search": Each 2 pieces fit together. Each must be positioned simultaneously on the board. The pairs are determined by the sound output of the Yvio. For example, a combination of "animal" / "loud noise". The stone with the sound output "elephant" should, therefore, a "Törööh" are assigned to stone - this is done through a trial and error "principle.
- "Order": In these challenges, the 8 stones are placed in an order (eg, single words to put together a lyrics or things will be sorted by size. Each stone solves it again exactly one sound).
- "Subset" Here, certain stones are sorted out following the instructions of the Yvio on the board.

Name: Yvio: Galileo Denkfitness
Description:
From the German publisher website:
Bei GALILEO DENKFITNESS gewinnt jeder! Denn die zum Teil recht anspruchsvollen Aufgaben halten das Gehirn fit und fordern Allgemeinwissen, Kombinationsvermögen und Auffassungsgabe heraus. Das Spiel bietet viel Knobelspaß und zeigt, wie jung unser Gehirn wirklich ist. Offenbart die Geheimnisse der Thinx und stellt ihre Beziehung zueinander in die richtige Reihenfolge!
- spielbar in drei verschiedenen Leveln
- immer neue Aufgaben fordern Suchtgefahr heraus
- Speicherung der Spielstände für verschiedene Personen
- als Einzel – und Gesellschaftsspiel spielbar

translated by Google Translate:
In GALILEO DENKFITNESS everyone wins! For some very challenging tasks the brain stays fit and challenges common knowledge, combined power and perception. The game offers plenty of puzzle fun and shows how young our brain really is. Reveals the secrets of Thinx and represents their relationship in the right order!
- playable in three different levels
- new tasks challenge Addiction
- Storing the scores for different people
- as an individual - and society playable game

Additional description:
"Denkfitness" is a thinking and logic game. The four basic pieces (from the main box) and the additional four pieces of the "Denkfitness" pack will be dressed in futuristic deco buildings. The goal of the game is to solve the puzzles by proper arrangement of the pieces on the eight fields of the board. The difficulty level rises from round to round. 
 In "Denkfitness" there are 3 different types of challenges:
- "Pair-search": Each 2 pieces fit together. Each must be positioned simultaneously on the board. The pairs are determined by the sound output of the Yvio. For example, a combination of "animal" / "loud noise". The stone with the sound output "elephant" should, therefore, a "Törööh" are assigned to stone - this is done through a trial and error "principle.
- "Order": In these challenges, the 8 stones are placed in an order (eg, single words to put together a lyrics or things will be sorted by size. Each stone solves it again exactly one sound).
- "Subset" Here, certain stones are sorted out following the instructions of the Yvio on the board.

Name: Circulo
Description:
Circulo is the world's first 4-in-1 circular strategy game; featuring four challenging games the whole family will enjoy, we're sure Circulo will become a favorite in your home for years to come!

4-in-a-Row: Players try to be the first to make a line of four tiles of their color in any direction to win!

Pipe Connections: The first player to complete a continuous pipe is the winner!

4 Letter Words: The first player to create a four letter word in any direction is the winner!

Sum of the Squares: The first player to line up tiles adding up to a total of seven is the winner!

Contents: 1 Circulo Game Tube with Cap, 1 Set of Pipe Connections Tiles, 1 Set of 4-in-a-Row Tiles, 1 Set of 4 Letter Words Tiles, 1 Set of Sum of the Squares Tiles

Name: Akebono
Description:
As day breaks upon Sekigahara pass, two armies stand ready to lay claim to the future of Japan. Two years before, Toyotomi Hideyoshi died leaving a son too young to rule. The council of regents sworn to defend his son split into two factions intent upon seizing power for themselves. As the fog lifts from the mountain pass, each faction stands poised for battle. Only the victor will witness the beginning of a new era in the history of Japan.

Akebono, the Japanese word meaning both “daybreak” and “beginning”, summarizes the tension and anticipation in the Sekigahara mountain pass, scene of the decisive battle of 1600 that would usher in the Edo period of Japanese history.

Akebono is a tactical dice driven game in which each player must present multiple flanks to ensure that at least some of the attacking troops will push forward. Units must be moved into a position to attack when their defeat is less likely.

In the end, the winner will be the player who best balances his aggressive and defensive tactics on the battlefield.

Name: The Pink Panther Chase Game
Description:
Pink Panther is a game for 2 to 4 players, in which one player pretends to be the Pink panther and the other players pretend to be either the Inspector, the Commissioner or the Constable. The Pink Panther is chased through the streets of Paris by the Inspector, the Commissioner and the Constable and has to reach the safety of one of his hideaways before he is caught

(from publisher's blurb)

Name: Caméléon
Description:
Description from BoardgameNews.com:

The Caméléon deck includes 54 combination cards, each with a number, a color and an object, along with a single wild chameleon card. Each player starts the round by drawing one of these cards and laying it face up on the table.

A randomly chosen dealer then turns over cards from the deck one by one, and any player who wants the card on the top of the stack must cover it with his hand, then name the three elements on the card. If he's correct, he claims the card; if he collects three cards, each with one of the three elements on his target card, he wins the round. The first player to win two rounds wins the game.

Name: Ghost Stories: Jean-Claude Van Rice
Description:
This is the 2010 Promotion available for download off the Repos website for April Fool's.

Jean-Claude is aware. When he enters play, he is sideways, filling 2 spaces (his color is considered green).  If there aren’t 2 free adjacent spaces due to Buddha or Ghosts, Jean-Claude makes space next to a free space by discarding what is there (no curse/reward for ghost; can't eliminate an incarnation).

To defeat him, players must break both his legs: his left leg has a 3 Blue resistance and his right 4 Green (his right leg is stronger).
An exorcism must be successful on each of his two legs (the order has no importance). When one of his legs is broken, he moves fully on to the space for the remaining leg, leaving an open space.

When both of his legs are broken, he is discarded and gives an apple to the active player (this reward is an artifact).  An apple is good for the body and it’s full of pectin, but it can spoil!  During his Yang Phase, the player can discard the apple to return any Taoist (including himself) to 3 QI. But if another Wu-Feng comes into play before the apple is used, the apple has spoiled and it must be discarded with no effect.
The apple cannot be used on a dead Taoist.

http://rprod.com/uploads/file/GHOST_STORIES_GOODIE_US_JCVD.pdf

---

Originally released as a downloadable card for April Fools Day 2010, which is when the above story initially ran on BGN, Jean-Claude Van Rice will be included in the limited edition version of 7 Wonders being released by Repos Production at Spiel 2010. I'm not sure whether other copies will be available for the grabbing, but if not, follow the info link above and download a copy for yourself. -boardgamenews.com

Name: De Race om de Kaap
Description:
This game takes place in the 17 and 18th century. Players have to buy a ship and sail from Europe to India. They have to sail around Africa. The players roll and move their boats. Players have to buy spices in India. The spices have to brought back to Europe, where the spices can be sold.
At the end of the game, the richest player wins.

Contents:
- 1 Board
- 2 dice
- 4 ship shaped pawns
- 52 cards

Name: Guacamole!
Description:
Publisher Blurb:

Looking for a spicy game to promote critical thinking? This clever new game has players frantically collecting all the ingredients for their own recipe of mild, medium or spicy guacamole! Be the first player to match 5 ingredients cards to the recipe card, and you get to keep that recipe card. Collect one of each type - mild, medium and spicy - and you win! Ole!

Game Overview:

Players are dealt five ingredient cards, which are laid face up in front of them.  The top recipe card is turned over and then players draw cards to improve their ingredients to match the recipe.  If a card is kept, another card is discarded, so that players only have five cards at a time.  Players may draw from the discard pile as well.  The first player to match the exact number of ingredients to the recipe shouts "Guacamole!" and then wins that recipe card.  The game continues until one player has won one each of the Mild, Medium and Spicy recipe cards.  The game can either be played by turns or by "scramble" (where all players draw and discard as fast as they can at the same time).

There are three special cards to spice things up: Limes - all players pass a card to their left; Salsa Bowl - all players pass a card to their right; Sombrero - all players get up and move one chair to the left, taking over another player's hand.

Name: The Game of Life: Rock Star Edition
Description:
Publisher Blurb:

You wanna be a rocker? Set the world on fire? Get on the Rock 'n Roll Highway and start your garage band, perform at the Red Roxy Amphitheater, get your first single on the radio and build fame and fortune. Live a rock star life, build your career, reach superstardom, become a Rock Star legend and retire at the Rocker’s Hall of Fame.

For those who want to rock, we salute you!

Game features one-time assembly and includes: Custom game board, 6 Tour Bus movers, 7 Rock ‘n Roll buildings, Rock Star spinner, 1 bridge, 3 mountain ranges, 52 Life tiles, 52 pegs and much more

Synopsis:

The Game of Life: Rock Star Edition is an interpretation of the popular Milton Bradley board game, with all the characters, places, events, and life decisions that are present in being a Rock Star. As the traditional version of the Game of Life has players finding jobs and starting families as they progress from space to space, the Rock Star edition has them starting a garage band and getting band members, while they follow life's path by performing at classic venues. By the time they make it to the end of the board -- Rocker's Hall of Fame -- the player who has the most fame and fortune wins the game.

Name: Clovis: The Dice Game
Description:
This is a dice-based version of the card game Clovis, which was released as a free Print and Play game early in 2009. The Dice game consists of 10 dice and a scoring sheet for each player. Players roll the dice to simulate hunting large game animals on the North American continent 12,000 years ago. There are special option dice which allow players to acquire more dice to roll and modify the results of their rolls. The game ends after the players jointly have accumulated a certain number of unsuccessful hunts (busts).

One major difference in Clovis: the Dice Game' from the original card game is the solo option. In a solo game of Clovis: the Dice Game you are challenged to earn 100 points or more to win.

Clovis: the Dice Game' Game is fast (10 - 20 minutes), easy to learn, easy to setup and put away, and best of all... FREE!!
Families: Versions & Editions: Dice Versions of Non-Dice Games

Name: MelodieXpress Note Reading
Description:
MelodieXpress - is it music poured into a game? ... or is it a game filled with music? It’s so hard to know!

Theme

At its heart MelodieXpress is a game about music. Actually it’s a whole lot of games about music. MelodieXpress uses a series of card games to teach the elements of music theory, and to teach the players the skills of sight-reading and composing music.

The pack includes playing cards based around music notation -  notes, clefs, key signatures, and accidental notes - as the basis for games and activities. While the overall intention it to foster musical knowledge and skills, the focus within the games is upon fun and enjoyment.

Gameplay

The Note Reading pack is the first of the MelodieXpress sets. It includes 104 cards including the treble, alto and base clefs, and 52 crotchet notes - 4 cards for each of 13 notes.

There are rules for 12 games included within the pack, and players are free to develop further games and activities utilising the flexibility of the cards. The guidebook introduces the basics of music notation and theory then leads on to the rules of the games.

The Basic Games

The 5 basic games introduce the notes and their naming to the point where players can instantly recognise and name the specific notes from the cards. These games utilise the crotchet notes and the clefs.

These basic games are designed to so that they can initially be played using a subset of 4 notes (16 cards). This allows players to become familiar with the notes and their names, then expanding to include additional notes. A clef is used next to the game board to define the specific notes (so with the treble clef play starts with middle C, D, E and F, while with the alto clef the same cards would be E, F, G and A). As players become confident and adept at naming the notes additional cards are introduced to expand the games and add complexity.

‘Introducing the Notes’ and ‘Flash Cards’ are the initial games and provide a first experience of notes and naming. They are followed by the classic ‘Snap’ and ‘Memory’ games adapted to be played using the music cards. While the players compete to win the games, the focus is upon ready recognition and matching of the notes on the cards. The final basic game - ‘Making Melodies’  encourages players to construct combinations of notes. It is also an opportunity to play the music from the cards for those players who are learning an instrument.

The basic games are fun and enjoyable in their own right, but also provide a platform for building an understanding of musical concepts and notation.

The Advanced Games

The 7 advanced games build upon the recognition and understanding of notes gained in the basic games. They focus upon sequences and progressions of notes and introduce the next level of sight reading. The later games also introduce the use of key signatures and accidental notes (sharps, flats and naturals) to further extend the game-play and learning.

‘Row’ and ‘Reach for the Stars’ are played by combining cards onto sequences of notes. Players place cards from their hands to build sequences of notes, either individually or in common. ‘Scale the Mountain’ extends on this by introducing key signatures, and requiring players to build sequences to complete the major scales. As play moves around the table individual players take turns to build upon the scale, or to introduce a new key signature and rearrange the sequence to match the new scale.

‘Chord you do it?’ and ‘Chords Aplenty’ focus upon players building three note sequences of chords to score points. Game-play is dynamic and can involve the trading or transfer of cards between players.

‘Rows and Scales’ and ‘Rows and Scales Advanced’ round out the advanced games, providing interactive games of sequencing and matching cards. Players seek to build sequences from scales and chord, utilising the note cards and accidentals to build legal sets.

Taking it Further

The game system is flexible and open ended. The variety of cards allows players and teachers to develop their own games and activities beyond those provided in the pack. 
Additional games will also be published on the MelodieXpress website, sharing new games and activities as they are developed.

The MelodieXpress System
 MelodieXpress is a fun, educational and easy way to learn to read music. 
Using the approach that we learn best through play, MelodieXpress uses games and activities to introduce the key concepts of musical notation and music theory. This step-by-step approach allows you to learn at your own pace, while the games provide an enjoyable way to learn and consolidate your knowledge of music.

Name: MelodieXpress Composing Music
Description:
The MelodieXpress Composing Music Pack takes up where the MelodieXpress Note Reading Pack leaves off. Composing Music adds more and cards and more games to extend the fun and increase the learning.

Overview

At its heart MelodieXpress is a collection of games about music. The packs include playing cards based around music notation - notes, clefs, key signatures and more. MelodieXpress uses a series of card games to teach the elements of music theory, and to teach the players the skills of sight-reading and composing music.

The Composing Music Pack brings further cards, along with its own guide book. New notes include semi breves, minims and quavers, and more accidental notes (sharps, flats and naturals). It also introduces time signatures - 2:4, 3:4, 4:4 and 6:8 time - plus bar lines and the key signatures for the Alto clef - (C major, G major, D major, A major, F major, B flat major and E flat major).

The focus is still on fun, but the additional cards in the Composing Music pack provide the basis for new games as well. The cards are combined with those from the Note Reading Pack to provide the expanded deck used in the new games.

Gameplay

The Guide Book provides some additional definitions and an introduction to the required music theory. It also presents 13 new games. Depending upon the game playing time can run from 5 to 30 minutes. The majority of the games cater for 2-6 players, though some can extend to include more if needed.

The early games build upon the skills developed in the Note Reading Pack, with games based around the key signatures, scales and chords. The later games make use of the new cards to introduce rhythm and melody.

‘Rhythm’ is a game for 2-6 players and introduces the use of key signatures and time signatures. Players progressively play cards from their hands to build up sequences of music. The grouping of notes must be consistent with the time signatures which start each sequence. As the game progresses players may add cards to their own or others sequences, aiming to build tunes of at least 18 notes.

‘Sure Time’ starts with a time signature and a sequence of 10 notes. Each player in turn chooses bar line and rest cards to introduce into the sequence and marks out each of the bars within the sequence of notes. Points are scored for correctly sequencing the cards. Each player faces a different combination of cards and time signatures as play progresses around the table.

‘Beat the Bar Line’ allows players to compose their own music. Each player progressively weaves together a communal collection of note cards with bar lines, rests and time signatures from their individual hands to build a growing composition. The game also introduces repeat bar lines and double bar lines with special rules for their play.

‘Composing Music’ adds additional challenges for those players who are learning an instrument or are taking choral lessons. Play starts with a player building a 3 bar segment of music built from the game cards. Points are scored based upon the composition. The following player in the sequence may then gain bonus points by correctly playing the piece. They then add a bar to the piece of music. Play continues with players alternately attempting to play the developing composition and then adding bars until all of the cards set out for that session have been used. Variations to the game allow for the substitution of different key signatures as the game progresses, as well as the use of accidental notes.

Taking it Further

Together the Note Reading and Composing Music Packs are intended to provide a fun series of games and activities which introduce the basics of sight reading and music notation. Additional packs and resources extend the system still further.

The game system is designed to be flexible and open ended. The variety of cards allows players and teachers to develop their own games and activities beyond those provided in the pack. 
Additional games will also be published on the MelodieXpress website, sharing new games and activities as they are developed.

The MelodieXpress System
 MelodieXpress is a fun, educational and easy way to learn to read music. Using the approach that we learn best through play, MelodieXpress uses games and activities to introduce the key concepts of musical notation and music theory. This step-by-step approach allows you to learn at your own pace, while the games provide an enjoyable way to learn and consolidate your knowledge of music.

MelodieXpress Composing Music is not a complete game. Ownership of MelodieXpress Note Reading is required.

ISBN 978-0-9807592-1-1
Patent Pending

[Publisher's Information]

Name: Tarot-Labyrint
Description:
On the board are the cards of the tarot shown. The outer circle consists of the 21 cards of the major Arcana. The inner circle is the minor arcana.

You need a Tarot deck of Rider Waite, a die, chips, pen and paper and a amulet.

Before the game begins the player ask themselves a question about his/her future. The players roll the die and move their amulet. Each card on the board contains a short oracle. Try to explain the card within your question. Some cards contain a instruction or refer to other cards. Try to fulfil the instructions or to understand (within your question) the other card.

You have to pay or receive chips depending on the card you landed with you amulet.

The game has no end. Usually, a group beforehand how long the game can last.

Name: Chromatic
Description:
An Abstract Game who represent a race between CMYK vs RGB.
Each player has 3 colors pieces, Cyan, Magent & Yellow, or Red, Green & Blue. Draws an hexagonal piece with 6 different colours in his 6 triangles, place it and move his colors using only 3 posibilities, that colour, his objetive colour (complementary) or his joker colour, (blacK for CMY or White for RGB. The first to take his pieces to his objetive colours win the game.

This game was also designed to have an educational aspect for art students

Name: Three Hoorays for the King
Description:
Ninth entry in TCS series of pnp wargames on English Civil War.
It features the battles of Adwalton Moor, Stratton and Cropredy Bridge.
It uses a chit drawing system to activate the leader, then proceeds with a simple method for resolving movement and combat, with great importance given to morale.

Each game features a single map (1A4 for Stratton and Adwalton Moor; 2A4 for Cropredy Bridge), plus 216 counters, 5 pages of rules and 2 pages of charts and tables.

Part of the English Civil War Series:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgamefamily/4086/tcs-ecw-series

Name: En Garde!: Inconceivable!
Description:
Expansion card for the base game, available as a convention give away.  This is a Fancy Move card that can only be played when you have no Poise left.

From the card: "You may discard all attacks against you, and any cards associated with those attacks from the field.  You may play this card against the Pistol, but if you do so, the attacker may play a new attack.

Name: Yvio: SpongeBob Schwammkopf Krosse Krabbe Express
Description:
Translated from the publisher's site:

Nothing beats the fresh Crab Burgers from Mr Krabs' Krusty Krab!. In order to deliver those burgers in time to the customers of Bikini Bottom, Spongebob®, Patrick, Squidward, and Sandy® have to hurry. This is possibly the world's fastest boardgame, where the players compete for the title "Employee of the month"! Only the fastest player making no mistakes can win!

Up to four players have to deliver their orders to the correct locations in time and must make sure that no other players steal their orders from under their noses!


     successful adaptation of the animated series
     (German) original voice talents from the TV series, cool sounds
     up to four players fight simultaneously


Works only in combination with the Yvio board game console.

Name: Havoc Expansion: John of Gaunt
Description:
User Summary

The John of Gaunt Expansion is a two-card expansion for Havoc: the Hundred Years War and cannot be played without the base game.

The expansion introduces John of Gaunt, son of Edward III, who led a series of lightning raids striking deep into France with a force of about 10,000 men. Later in life he helped his brother's son (Richard II) consolidate power during his reign.

John creates his own special battle when he comes into the game before "retiring" to his estate.

Components:
- 1 Rules sheet (double-sided with English & German instructions)
- 1 John of Gaunt card, to be added to the regular HAVOC deck
- 1 Chevauchees Battle card, two-sided (Side 1 is Calais to Tours, side 2 is Tours to Bordeaux)
- 1 Plastic ziplock bag for Havoc game Tokens

It appears that this expansion, and a few other promos, were later combined to form the Havoc Character Card expansion.

Name: HAVOC: Tactical Miniature Warfare
Description:
2010 Origins Nominee for Best Miniature Rules

The moment...

There is the slightest of pauses between the rushing sound of arrows parting the air, and the thudding impacts of bodkin tips on shield, armor, and flesh. It is in this pause that fear and doubt creep in; it is in this pause that warriors learn if they are truly meant for battle.

Sounds...

Trumpets sound the maneuver, banners snap in the breeze, knights impact infantry with thunderous results, Behemoths bellow, blackpowder roars, and there is the singing of metal-on-metal.

'The Named'...

Challenges are made and accepted. Berserkers frenzy. Champions defend. Executioners finish. Zombies feast. Giants smash and fling. With each confrontation new names and legends are forged while other stories find their ending.

Enter the world of HAVOC....
and conduct tactical battles on the tabletop. The Core Edition of HAVOC has all the rules you need to start playing. All you supply are some 6 sided dice, miniatures, and measuring tape.

Use any miniatures, from any manufacturer!
Go in to battle with the models of your choosing.

The Core Edition contains the entire HAVOC Game System!
O.D.D.S. Combat, 'Chain Reaction' Activations featuring Organic Formations, Wreaking Havoc!, Arrow-Time, Magicks & Arcanum, Cut Scenes, The Rules of Form- it's all in there and more...

Scenarios & Situations...
that will test your strategic planning and tactical flexibility in equal measure.

'The Named'
Upgrade your standard troop models by giving them a 'Name' such as: Berserker, Dragoon, Giant, Hydra, Magus, or Zombie (just to name a few).

'HAVOC... it's okay to wreak a little!'

Name: Iconica Series #1 Add-on Cards
Description: While the base Iconica set contains enough cards for a simple 1 vs. 1 game, additional cards are necessary to provide 2 vs. 2 team play or further variety in play styles in 1v1 games. These Series #1 cards expand the base game by adding additional playable characters.

Name: Mecca
Description:
We are in Mecca, the holiest Islamic city in Saudi Arabia and prophet Muhammad's birthplace.

Year after year, Mecca receives more than a three million faithful on one of their faith's pillars: the Holy Pilgrimage or Hajj. We are going to access the inside of the Holy Mosque of Mecca right now, the main shrine of Muslim pilgrimage during the Hajj... the imposing Sacred Kaaba is just in front of us...  In order to avoid crowds during the massive influx of the faithful in the Holy Mosque the organizers have devised an innovative system to control the placement and organization of the pilgrims during their prayers to Allah.

The player who successfully introduces more pilgrims in the Holy Place according to this organization system will be the winner.


La Meca es la principal ciudad de la región del Hiyaz, en la actual Arabia Saudita, y una de las más importantes de la península de Arabia. Para los musulmanes, el peregrinaje a La Meca forma parte de uno de los aspectos fundamentales de su fe, los denominados pilares del Islam.

Cada año, cerca de tres millones de peregrinos se dirigen a la Ciudad Santa para realizar el peregrinaje mayor o Hajj durante el mes musulmán de du l-hiyya. Muchos más hacen la peregrinación menor o Umrah, que puede realizarse durante todo el año. Muy pocos no musulmanes han podido ver los ritos y rituales del Hajj, ya que está totalmente prohibida la entrada de no creyentes en La Meca. Con el fin de que no se produzcan aglomeraciones durante el Hajj, en la Mezquita Sagrada han ideado un sistema de colocación y reorganización para controlar a los peregrinos.

El jugador que consiga introducir más peregrinos en el recinto sagrado será el ganador.

Name: Red Alert! Shields Up!
Description:
User summary: A fast-play set of miniature rules for ship-to-ship combat in the Star Trek universe published in Issue 18 of Battlegames Magazine. They adapt Full Thrust to hex-play and replace damage rolls with a draw deck. Two scenarios are included with the rules.

Requirements:

Players will require these rules, several six-sided dice (d6), ship diagrams (provided), miniatures or counters representing ships, and a hex-grid. Micromachines make excellent and inexpensive miniatures in roughly 1/3700 scale.

Game Overview:

Players control 1-5 space ships and plot simultaneous turns. Movement is 2-D cinematic flight with basic momentum incorporated into the the movement mechanic. Games end when one side reaches its break point or accomplished its scenario objectives.

Combat is based on variable numbers of d6s (depending on weapon and range). When ships reach damage thresholds, players draw a card from a damage deck and apply the results (usually bad, sometimes good).

Full stats for Federation and Klingon ships as well as ship status displays are available in the magazine and on the Battlegames website: http://www.battlegames.co.uk/dispatches/dispatches_fanscifi.html .

Name: Loot Ninja
Description:
Loot Ninja is a fast-paced dexterity/puzzle hybrid game in which players take on the role of adventurers vying for the supreme loot collection!

Each player has a backpack which they must attempt to fill as efficiently as possible with polyiamond "loot" tiles. Gameplay consists of players throwing dice at tiles in an attempt to grab the most desirable items before their so-called friends can get their grubby little paws on them! Proximity is the goal, but beware... some items have effects that can modify the layout or content of the loot drop!

Name: Scoreboard Tennis
Description: Scoreboard Tennis is Inside Sports' latest addition to our Quick Play line of games.  All players are rated for each surface they played on, based on their real life performance.  With each season that is rated, any match-up can be replayed on your tabletop.  You can even replay entire Grand Slam tournaments.  Scoreboard Tennis offers two different quick play options.  You can choose to play a match either Set by Set or Game by Game with just a single roll of the dice determining the winner of the set or game.  Scoreboard Tennis is the perfect companion to Inside Sports' Inside Volley Tennis game.  With these two games combined, you have the option to play a match Set by Set, Game by Game, or Point by Point.  The choice is yours.  No other tennis game on the market offers this kind of versatility!

Name: Star Block
Description:
From the back of the box:

GET TO CRYSTAL CITY BEFORE THE ROBOTS TAKE OVER

A landing party from the starship "Aurora" beams down to explore an uncharted planet in search of provisions.  The spacemen meet unfriendly robots who move about trying to keep the "invaders" from entering Crystal City.  But the spacemen need supplies, so they plot thier course over the alien surface in a bid to occupy Crystal City before the robots can take over their landing site.


     * *


User Summary:

In Star Block, each player controls five pieces, either spacemen or robots.  The two forces start on opposite sides of a board consisting of forty-four pentagon-shaped spaces.  The object is to be the first player to occupy all five spaces of the opponent's starting row.  Pieces may neither be captured nor jumped; however, pieces may be blocked (hence the name of the game).

Name: Palagonia
Description:
Palagonia is an alternative game played with Palago tiles, but it is not at all a variant of Palago. Palago is a two player perfect information abstract, Palagonia is a game of luck, creativity and co-operation for 3 to 5 players.

Players add tiles to a central pattern to form closed shapes which are called "creatures". The roll of the dice may cause tiles to be removed or rotated as well. When a creature is formed, the player and the previous player score points based on the size and complexity of the creature. When the tiles run out, the player with the most points wins.

Name: Arne Expansion
Description:
With this expansion you can play Arne up to 6 players.

Contents: 48 cards

Name: Quadrat
Description:
Quadrat is a dice driven but strategic capturing game.
The aim of the game is to capture your oppnents pieces by building a square around them. 
Each turn you first roll a dice that indicats how many of your pieces you have to move, and how far.
After you have moved them, you check if 4 of them build a square (no matter how big). If there is a square, remove all oposing pieces inside. 
As soon as a player has only 4 or less pieces left, he loses the game.

contents:
1 board
1 dice (6-sided)
24 cubes (12 of each colour)

Name: Poland Aflame!
Description:
Poland Aflame! is an Advanced Squad Leader campaign package that contains a series on interrelated scenarios pertaining to the German invasion of Poland starting on September 1st, 1939. A number of scenarios are played, each simulating a portion of the action, that took place on that date. The ASL Rulebook is required, and special rules that apply to this campaign series are listed in this expansion.

The rules of this campaign package allows players to make use of a special phase called the Refit Phase, wherein each side takes stock of what happened and prepares for further combat in the next scenario. Reinforcement Groups in the form of infantry companies, Armored platoons, OBA modules and Gun Batteries - to name a few - may be selected by the players and purchased through the expenditure of Campaign purchase points. Players will soon find that the last-ditch, suicidal charge so often employed in a standard scenario may be needlessly costly to their chances for victory in the overall campaign.

Name: Kelgukoerad: Kes tappis kirjakandja?
Description:
From the publisher:
Detectives will get a call into suburbia, where there have happened a murder. An old lady who went after the very early morning newspaper found a dead mailman behind her fence. All signs show brutal murder. Very fast 4 suspects emerge and your job is to help detectives to find out who killed the mailman!!

New expansion to game "Kelgukoerad".

Content:
new case file
32 new vidence cards
8 "new blind luck" cards
envelope with an answer

Name: Kelgukoerad: Kuhu kadus karu?
Description:
From the publisher:
Detectives get called to a zoo, where last night a little cup was robbed. Now it is up to you to find out who is responsible.

New expansion to game "Kelgukoerad". This one is for kids.

Content:
new case file
32 new vidence cards
8 "new blind luck" cards
envelope with an answer

Name: The Ivory Castle Game
Description:
Advertisers variant of Snakes and Ladders, produced in 1935 to advertise D& W Gibbs "Dentifrice" Toothpaste.

Size approx.35cm X 46cm when unfolded (central fold). Printed on cardboard - board has two holes and a string at the top to allow it to be hung up as an advertising item. Rules are printed on the rear of the board.

Includes dice and 4 coloured counters.

Game was posted in a pink envelope with the rules printed on them. Publisher unknown, but game was produced for D & W Gibbs Ltd, Wapping, London E1.

The object of the game is to reach the land of Health and Happiness, and the player who gets there first wins. Along the way there are various difficulties to help and hinder the player; for example, the Gibbs Fairy helps, an Imp hinders, and a Giant (called Decay!) handicaps the player at the start of the game. Various spaces have actions associated with them, that send the player to other squares. A roll and move mechanism with a standard six sided die is used to determine each players movement.

Unusual variant of Snakes and Ladders, produced by the Gibbs toothpaste company to promote their products and raise awareness of dental hygiene. Who said that games weren't good for you?

Other links:
http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=334946

Name: Hase Hatschi
Description: Hase Hatschi is a card drawing and counting game for kids age 4 and up. In this game, the bunnies on every card got the cold, and every time a proposed card is drawn, the player shouting "Hatschi" first, get's a point.

Name: Twilight Vigilance
Description:
Twilight Vigilance: A chance to experience the many challenges of the Cold War while attempting to contain the spread of communism.

Solitaire game of the Cold War, using VPG's States of Siege card driven mechanics, first seen in Israeli Independence.

The player is embroiled in the Cold War and must stop the Communist overthrow of the United States. The player allocates national resources to different budgetary areas, including Military, Diplomacy, Espionage, Technology and Economy. The correct balance must be maintained in the face of different events drawn from the deck.

Name: Nex
Description:
Nex is an abstract strategy game for 2 - 4 players. Gameplay consist of players taking turns to either place or move one of their pieces on the board. The goal is to force the other players into a position where they can't make any legal moves. This can be done either by capturing enough of their peices or by maneuvering their pieces into a corner.

This game is no longer available as Nex. It has been rethemed and after a few rules tweaks released as Battle of 4 Armies.

Name: Terra Kids: Länder der Welt
Description:
Geography trivia games for children. The board shows a map of the world and flags of over 50 countries. The active player gets one hint and has to correctly name the country - the hint might be a number on the world map, the flag or the capital city. When a player knows the country with one hint, he/she proceeds three fields. When two hints are necessary, one field. When three are necessary, one field. The first player to reach the finish line is the winner.
Depending on the current position, the categories can be chosen or are pre-determined. If a player cannot guess the correct country even after three hints, he/she stays in position and gets a wild card. A player with two wild cards has to discard them and gets to name a country that was already used in the game again.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Name: Trial of Grandis
Description:
Intro
It is a time of wizardry and power. In the esteemed Academia Magicas, novices from the House of Elementas shall be given their final test: Trial of Grandis. As a Chief Apprentice of your Noble House, you shall lead a quartet of novices through a maze of primordial elements on the ancient Fields of Grandis to earn your Elementor ranks and stand as honoured Magi of Magicas.

Basic Mechanics
- Your objective is to win as much Victory Points (VPs) as possible, while striding through each terrain square to reach the end of the field. 
- The Trial ends when all terrain squares at the finishing line are occupied.
- Each Player begins with 5 cards in his/her hand and draws 2 extra cards at the start of turn.
- Each Player may conduct a maximum of 3 movement/actions with his/her playing cards during a turn.
- Each Player can hold as many cards as he/she can in hand at the end of turn, but beware of the thief.

Cards
- There are 2 types of Cards that can be drawn from the draw deck: Scroll Cards and Action Cards.
- Scroll Cards are used for basic movement to each terrain square (see movement)
- Action Cards are special magic scrolls with extra spells such as VP Thief, Revive Mana and etc that can be used to your advantage.

Movement
- The Field of Grandis is a land of power, with terrains warded by elements that bars entrance from those who do not wield them. 
- Fire, Ice, Thunder and Poison Wards of varying degrees protect each terrain. 
- To stride the fields, you must be proficient in utilizing the Elementas Scrolls (Cards) to calm the elements of each terrain.
- You can move straight or diagonal to the adjoining square by casting your Scroll Cards according to the element and number of scrolls required. e.g. A square guarded by a Level 2 Fire Ward can only be entered by casting 2 Fire Scrolls (cards).

Victory Points
- The field is divided into sections, each section of terrain squares with their own VP value, ascending to the highest VP value at the finishing squares.
- At game end, only the VP value of the terrain squares occupied by each of your Novices is accumulated.
- VP Points can also be earned by performing the Lock Spell (see Lock Spell)
- Player with the most accumulated VPs wins the game.

Lock Spell
- When 2 or more Novices move into the same terrain square, the latest Novice to arrive at the square automatically performs a Lock Spell on the Novice(s) before it.
- Novice under the Lock Spell cannot perform any movement or action until the spell-caster moves away from the square OR the spell is broken with a Lock Breaker action card.
- There is no limit to the number of Novices occupying a square; the last Novice to enter a square will always be the spell-caster.

Trial of Grandis is a strategy card + board game with a minimum luck factor in drawing cards.

Free downloadable files (print & play game board, rules of play, etc) will be available soon.

Name: Gute Reise, Kleiner Rabe
Description:
A game in the "Kleiner Rabe" (little raven) series of children's games based on the book series by author Nele Moost and illustrator Annet Rudolph.

Contents: 32 cards

The rules describe 5 variants to traditional card games:
- Alle Viere: a variant of happy families
- Gleich und Gleich: memory
- Eins, zwei, drei: a rummy variant
- Aufgepasst: a dexterity game
- Angeschmiert: a variant of old maid

Name: Kronen Zeitung: Das Quiz
Description:
Trivia game in which the goal is to advance on a career ladder (from intern to editor in chief). The players take turns rolling a die. When they land on a normal field, they have to answer the question with the same number they rolled from a card with six questions. When answering correctly, they can roll again. On a "category field", a player has to answer a question from that particular category to advance on the ladder. The first to become editor in chief wins the game.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Name: Dig In!
Description:
From Designer: Two teams of Dwarves battle it out for control of areas. Players can use special cards that invoke the ability of the gods to attempt to gain the upper hand, but be warned! Each team has a limited supply of troops and once that supply is gone you will have no more reinforcements.

Players will engage each other in skirmish like battles to gain control over 6-7 locations. Locations are worth additional points if controlled by it's matching teams, thus the players must strategically place their units and decide when and where to attack.

To add variety there are are 30+ community cards which each player draws from to attempt to gain an advantage.

During the 8 rounds of the game players will place their units, use power ups, and attack each other. Movement of the units once placed is very limited so it is important to place the units in regard to where the player wants them to end up.

The game comes with 54 cards, instructions, and 2 dice. The game has been designed so that it is not required to reshuffle the cards except between games, ensuring that downtime is at a minimum.

Name: Pincer
Description:
Entry for the Chessex Tribute competition.

Game Overview
The object of the game is to capture your opponents’ dice by either trapping them with a die on two opposing sides (performing a pincer movement) or by dropping a die of the same number on top of it.

Components
. Game board (15 x 15 squares)
. 36 dice x number of players (72 for 2 player, 108 for 3 player, 144 for 4 players) – each player should have a different colour of dice
. These Rules
. Diagonal Arrow Tiles x 30 (Optional)

Set Up
. - If using arrow tiles, place them 3 at a time (alternating who puts them down) on the board wherever you like.
. - Players roll their dice 6 at a time and place them on their side of the board. Alternate putting dice on the board. You can place them within the five rows closest to them on the board (exactly where is generally irrelevant, but can ultimately be used as some sort of strategy depending on how you put them down). Keep doing this until each player has at least 30 dice on the board.
.... - You may opt to hold 6 dice in reserve so you can place them in game at a later time.
.... - When you play these reserves you can put any number of them on the board at a time, so long as they are on your own side of the board. Remember to roll them first to determine which side is facing up.
. - Starting a die on the board so that it pincers an opponent’s die does not count as a capture.
. - Designate starting player.

Arrow Tiles
. Landing on an arrow tile grants you an additional direction to move in - always a diagonal. If the arrow points up and to the left, then you may move up, down, left, right, or up-left.

Rules for Play
. - Players alternate moving one die each turn.
. - If you drop one of your dice on another one of your dice, the die at the bottom is removed and can be replayed on a later turn with a different number on its face.
. - Any dice captured by your opponent are removed from the game. You don’t get them back during this game.
. - A die can jump in any of the four directions provided they a) stay on the board, and b) don’t land on an enemy die with a number different to the die you are moving. You can drop any of your dice on top of any of your own dice, provided they are in range.
. - You can only move your pieces in a straight line.
. - If you jump your dice between two enemy dice, you don’t lose that die. The opponent must manoeuvre into a position where they jump beside you.

Reinforcements
You can play any number of reinforcements in your home zone (the first five lines on your side of the board) on your turn instead of moving one of your dice.
If you place a reinforcement next to an opponent’s die that already has one of your dice on an opposing side, it does not count as a capture.

Buffer
One line of squares running from corner to corner of the board should act as a buffer if you intend to have more than 2 people playing a game. I.e. during initial deployment, you cannot place one of your own dice next to an opponent’s dice.

Dice Rules
. - Number 1 Dice: can move one square, capture enemy Number 1 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
. - Number 2 Dice: can move 2 squares, capture enemy Number 2 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
. - Number 3 Dice: can move 3 squares, capture enemy Number 3 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
. - Number 4 Dice: can move 4 squares, capture enemy Number 4 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
. - Number 5 Dice: can move 5 squares, capture enemy Number 5 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
. - Number 6 Dice: can move 6 squares, capture enemy Number 6 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
- Capture: Jumping on an enemy die with the same number on its face. Moving your dice into position so that there is one of your dice on either side (left and right or front and back) of a die with any number on its face.

Board Shape
It was recently brought to my attention that the game can be played on grids that aren't necessarily square. To play on a triangular board, your pieces can move normally in all 6 directions, thus rendering the need for the arrow toils null.

Winning
. Players who have less than 6 dice left on the board (with no reserves) lose. A player may concede defeat any time after they are reduced to ten dice less than their opponent (e.g. if they have 15 dice and their opponent has 25 dice, they can concede defeat).

Name: Crime Crushers
Description:
From the side of the box:

"... a game of criminal pursuit, is a fast-paced, simulated street cop role-playing game that looks at the humorous side of law enforcement as it relates to the patrol division ..."

Players take turns rolling the dice and moving about the game board. Landing on various locations, players draw cards from various decks, which in turn cause good and bad events to happen. Events will cause a gain or loss in points, until one player reaches the point goal required to win the game.

Name: Diamond Bridge
Description:
From the designer's website (www.diamondbridgegame.com):

Diamond Bridge is a strategy game for two to four players. The board has a diamond-shaped grid, four corner pits and gems of two colors.

To play, take turns placing a gem on any open dot on the board.

The object of the game is to bridge sides of your color with an unbroken string of gems.

The game always results in one player completing a bridge or the other giving up. There is no deadlock.

The corner dots count for either color.

A player who spans side-to-side calls out, "Diamond Bridge!"

The game concept is basic. Players try to bridge sides of their color. It's fun to play "right out of the box." For the serious player the complexity of Diamond Bridge soon becomes apparent. Mastering the game requires a sense of balance, spatial reasoning and sustained focus.

How does this game differ from the classic earlier game Hex?
1. In Diamond Bridge, a player has only 16 pieces, and once a player has placed all their pieces, they then move an already-placed piece on their turn.
2. Diamond Bridge has no swap rule, so there is a significant first player advantage.

Name: ESCANDALOS
Description:
Is a game for adults that was concibe in the rumors about facts, peoples and situations publics that wake up the interest of the society in argentina and the world.Is a recopilation of 1080 scandals in 5 themes

1)arts ( literature,music,painting)
2)movies
3)miscelaneas
4)history
5)financiary

es un juego para adultos que no ha sido concebido sobre una memoria académica rigurosa y precisa. Se apoya en el "boca a boca" de situaciones que se hicieron públicas y que despertaron el interés general, sea por las circunstamcias que las rodearon, sea por sus protagonistas, o por lo que sea.
Es una recopilaciónde 1.080 escándalos de los ámbitos: POLITICA-ECONOMIA-DEPORTES-ESPECTACULOS en 5 cuadernillos subdivididos en:

* ARTES (Literatura-pintura-música-etc)
    * CINE Y MEDIOS (tv-prensa y radio)
    * VARIOS (juegos-deportes-naturaleza-drogas-accidentes-etc)
    * POLITICOS E HISTORICOS
    * JUDICIALES Y FINANCIEROS

Name: Godet Hill
Description:
First ASL scenario designed by French ASL'er Michel Bongiovanni, pits elements of the German Grenadier Regiment 980 against the British elements of the 7st Black Watch and 1st Northamptonshire Yeomanry. This expansion of the Advanced Squad Leader game system simulates squad level warfare based on historical information. For this scenario, the date is 16th August 1944, the location is St Pierre-sur-Dives, France.

Part of Operation Paddle, the British goal is take the town of Lisieux. In the morning of 16th August, a bridge of the Dives was secured, and the 154th Infantry Brigade sped forward to reach the Oudon. But the leading tanks and armoured cars was greeted by a hail of fire coming from the Godet Hill standing before the river. The commanding heights must be seized until the river could be reached.

Victory Conditions : The British win at game end if
there is no good order German Multi Man Counter or vehicle with
functioning MA on level 2 hill hexes.

Requires ASL British and German Orders of Battle, game boards 6 and 47.

Source of Description: paraphrase of the scenario itself

Name: Una serata a Saint Vincent: con Tony Binarelli
Description:
(Text extracted from the introduction of the game, written by Tony Binarelli)

"The noise of the ball that bounces on the roulette wheel. The rustle of cards that slip on the green table. The sound of dice shaken in the dice-box. The murmur of the players. The silence of expectation. The blue smoke of cigarettes. Anxiety, joy, frustration depicted by the gambling on the faces of the crowd around the tables. This is the atmosphere in the halls of a casino. A thrilling atmosphere that attracts and disrupts all your senses. An extraordinary and unrepeatable sensation that Fortune gives you when filling your pockets with money or taking away everything you have. Because, in fact, winning does not matter.  What is important is risking and defying the Fate at that beloved and, at the same time, hated green table.
The purpose of this game is just to give everyone a chance to try these feelings, tempting fate seamless. Come with me and your friends to spend an evening at this very special casino every time you want. You will not regret. Challenge your luck with roulette, poker, telesina, Macao, s1ot machines and many other exciting and funny games. If you are cautious, intelligent and, above all, lucky, you will have the chance not only to clean your playmates out, but also to break the bank of the casino and become the King of Players".

The game is composed by:
